historicalContext.catalyst: Eris threw golden apple inscribed 'To the Fairest' among goddesses
historicalContext.trigger: Wedding of Peleus and Thetis (parents of Achilles) - all gods invited except Eris (Discord)
historicalContext.timeframe: Events leading to Trojan War (mythological Bronze Age)
historicalContext.setting: Mount Ida, where Paris shepherded flocks after being exposed as infant

significance.fatalShortsi ghtedness: Paris chooses immediate gratification over long-term consequences
significance.choiceOfValues: Represents eternal dilemma of choosing among power, wisdom, and love
significance.divineVanity: Goddesses' willingness to bribe mortal reveals divine pettiness
significance.moralCaughtInDivinePolitics: Mortal thrust into cosmic disputes beyond comprehension
significance.prophecyFulfilled: Paris's mother dreamed of torch destroying Troy - his choice fulfills prophecy

narrativeStructure.climax: Paris awards apple to Aphrodite, choosing love over power/wisdom

bribes.athena: Wisdom, skill in warfare, victory in all battles
bribes.hera: Power and kingship over all of Europe and Asia
bribes.aphrodite: Love of the most beautiful woman in the world (Helen)

narrativeStructure.setup: Eris excluded from wedding, throws apple of discord
narrativeStructure.conflict: Three goddesses (Hera, Athena, Aphrodite) each claim the apple
narrativeStructure.consequence: Paris abducts/elopes with Helen, sparking Trojan War
narrativeStructure.complication: Zeus refuses to judge, appoints mortal Paris

description: The Judgment of Paris is one of Greek mythology's most consequential tales - a beauty contest among three goddesses that ignited the Trojan War. When Paris, prince of Troy, was forced to judge who was fairest among Hera, Athena, and Aphrodite, his choice set in motion a decade-long war that destroyed civilizations and birthed epic poetry.
relatedConcepts: Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned
Achilles - Son of Thetis and Peleus
name: Greek Mythology

artisticLegacy.modernRetellings: Contemporary authors reimagine from various perspectives (Madeline Miller, Margaret Atwood, Pat Barker)
artisticLegacy.renaissance: Immensely popular allowing artists to paint three female nudes (Cranach, Rubens, Watteau, Boucher)
artisticLegacy.ancientArt: Frequently depicted on Greek vases - three goddesses before seated Paris

primarySources: Cypria (lost epic) - Earliest detailed account, 7th century BCE
Homer's Iliad - Allusions to judgment, 8th century BCE
Euripides' plays - Iphigenia at Aulis, Helen
Lucian's Dialogues of the Gods - Satirical version, 2nd century CE
participants: Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned
